description: From Middle English feaute, feute, from Anglo-Norman fëauté, fëuté, from Latin fidēlitās (“faithfulness”; “homage, fealty” in Medieval Latin), from fidēlis (“faithful”) +‎ -tās (noun suffix); the modern form (for expected *feauty /ˈfjuːti/) is due to learned influence. Equivalent to obsolete feal +‎ -ty. Doublet of fidelity.

entries.meaning: Fidelity to one's lord or master; the feudal obligation by which the tenant or vassal was bound to be faithful to his lord.
The oath by which this obligation was assumed.
